description: From Middle English hoke, from Old English hōc.

verbs.description: hoke (third-person singular simple present hokes, present participle hoking, simple past and past participle hoked)

entries.meaning: (slang) To ascribe a false or artificial quality to; to pretend falsely to have some quality or to be doing something, etc.
examples: He even checked the Thomas Cooke & Son travel people about how to get to the East End (here he was hoking a bit), learning that they were ready to advise him on how to journey to any point in the world except the East End. Then he hailed a cab and found (here he was hoking further) that the cab driver didn't know how to get there either.

description: From the root of holk (“hollow cavity”). Compare Scots howk.

verbs.description: hoke (third-person singular simple present hokes, present participle hoking, simple past and past participle hoked)

examples: When I hoked there, I would find / An acorn and a rusted bolt
